Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Fundamental Studies on Mechanics of Three Dimensional Random Fiber Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to investigate the microstructural and mechanical properties of materials composed of randomly cross-linked fibers. Fibrous materials are ubiquitous, multifunctional entities with distinctive benefits such as high specific stiffness and adjustable mechanical properties. In these materials, regardless of the intended functions, a filamentous skeleton provides the structural integrity against external forces. In this research, state-of-the-art computational models and novel analysis tools will be created to determine the underlying physical mechanisms which govern the mechanics of three dimensional fiber networks. Specifically, a multiscale model will be developed to bridge different length scales and characterize the mechanical behavior in terms of morphological and microstructural properties. This research will establish a new way of thinking about the mechanics of three-dimensional fiber networks and its relationship to the spatial distribution, assembly, and structural properties of the constituents.

The creation of new knowledge on the key mechanisms governing the mechanics of generic three-dimensional fiber networks is expected to carry significant potential for creating a more complete understanding of mechanical properties of biological and manmade materials such as the cell cytoskeleton, collagenous soft tissue, blood clots, battery substrates, filters, and paper products. Therefore, the outcomes of this project will be of great importance not only from a computational mechanics perspective but also as a computational framework for other scientists investigating properties of filamentous materials. A comprehensive educational plan and outreach activities are also planned to enhance the engagement of high school students in science and engineering disciplines, and to train the next generation of diverse and capable scientists and engineers. Presentations on the general topics of engineering will be given to the high school students, an engineering project based on this research will be developed for the incoming freshman students, and undergraduate and graduate students will be mentored to gain the required training for independent research in the field of mechanics of materials.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this project was to investigate the microstructural and mechanical properties of randomly cross-linked semiflexible fiber networks. These fiber networks are broadly encountered in biological and manmade materials such as cell cytoskeleton, extracellular matrix, filters, and paper products. The elasticity of semiflexible networks is different from that of their flexible counterparts because of the relatively large bending stiffness of their constituting fibers. This notable feature leads to unique mechanical properties, such as strain stiffening and negative normal stress, that are not seen in flexible polymer networks. In this project, we developed novel numerical models for characterizing the underlying mechanisms that govern the mechanics of random fiber networks.  The most significant findings are as follows.

We created three dimensional random fiber networks and introduced a strain-based nonaffinity measure for probing their mechanical response at different length scales. We found that the amount of nonaffinity is a function of network fiber density, bending stiffness of the constituent fibers, and the network architecture.  We also investigated the microstructural and mechanical response of three-dimensional gel networks using a new interparticle interaction potential. We concluded that, in addition to topology, local mechanical interactions between particles play a significant role in defining the mechanical response of gel networks. We investigated the influence of network architecture on the numerical results by characterizing the mechanical response of random fiber networks generated from growing fibers from randomly positioned seed points. This alternative generation algorithm, although computationally more involved, is better suited for characterizing the properties of fibrous materials such as collagenous tissues. Furthermore, we developed a new numerical model in which two intersecting fibers were connected to each other by torsional springs with adjustable stiffness. This was done to assess the influence of commonly used simplifying assumption in literature that the crosslinks between two fibers are modelled as rigidly welded or pinned together (only partial constraint exists at the crosslinks in actual biological networks). One of the unique features of random fiber networks is that they show an unusual exponential strain-stiffening behavior when subjected to mechanical loads. We conducted comprehensive study of large deformation of random fiber networks in order to show that the material properties of individual fibers, in addition to network microstructure and bending stiffness of the fibers, play an important role in defining their nonlinear mechanical response. We found that increasing the amount of nonlinearity in the stress-strain response of individual fibers creates a homogeneous local strain distribution throughout the networks. The influence of prestress, the presence of residual stresses in unloaded random networks, was also thoroughly investigated. We showed that although random networks soften under initial compression, they stiffen significantly with the application of the initial extension. The effects of geometric disorder, randomness in the stiffness of individual fibers, network connectivity and bending rigidity of fibers on these numerical findings were discussed.

These studies created new knowledge on the key mechanisms governing the mechanics of random fiber networks and provided a better understanding of mechanical properties of biological and manmade materials such as the cell cytoskeleton, extracellular matrix, and paper products. Furthermore, these studies could be used to guide scientific efforts to design new biomimetic materials that possess mechanical and microstructral properties similar to those of natural and biological fibrous materials. The findings of this project appeared in a number of peer-reviewed journal publications. Furthermore, several presentations were given at the national and international conferences and meetings. This project supported a graduate student who defended his PhD thesis successfully. Furthermore, a new graduate course was developed and added to the curriculum. 

 


Last Modified: 12/24/2020
Modified by: Hamed Hatami-Marbini
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The research objective of this project was to investigate the microstructural and mechanical properties of randomly cross-linked semiflexible fiber networks. These fiber networks are broadly encountered in biological and manmade materials such as cell cytoskeleton, extracellular matrix, filters, and paper products. The elasticity of semiflexible networks is different from that of their flexible counterparts because of the relatively large bending stiffness of their constituting fibers. This notable feature leads to unique mechanical properties, such as strain stiffening and negative normal stress, that are not seen in flexible polymer networks. In this project, we developed novel numerical models for characterizing the underlying mechanisms that govern the mechanics of random fiber networks. The most significant findings are as follows. We created three dimensional random fiber networks and introduced a strain-based nonaffinity measure for probing their mechanical response at different length scales. We found that the amount of nonaffinity is a function of network fiber density, bending stiffness of the constituent fibers, and the network architecture. We also investigated the microstructural and mechanical response of three-dimensional gel networks using a new interparticle interaction potential. We concluded that, in addition to topology, local mechanical interactions between particles play a significant role in defining the mechanical response of gel networks. We investigated the influence of network architecture on the numerical results by characterizing the mechanical response of random fiber networks generated from growing fibers from randomly positioned seed points. This alternative generation algorithm, although computationally more involved, is better suited for characterizing the properties of fibrous materials such as collagenous tissues. Furthermore, we developed a new numerical model in which two intersecting fibers were connected to each other by torsional springs with adjustable stiffness. This was done to assess the influence of commonly used simplifying assumption in literature that the crosslinks between two fibers are modelled as rigidly welded or pinned together (only partial constraint exists at the crosslinks in actual biological networks). One of the unique features of random fiber networks is that they show an unusual exponential strain-stiffening behavior when subjected to mechanical loads. We conducted comprehensive study of large deformation of random fiber networks in order to show that the material properties of individual fibers, in addition to network microstructure and bending stiffness of the fibers, play an important role in defining their nonlinear mechanical response. We found that increasing the amount of nonlinearity in the stress-strain response of individual fibers creates a homogeneous local strain distribution throughout the networks. We showed that although random networks soften under initial compression, they stiffen significantly with the application of the initial extension. These studies created new knowledge on the key mechanisms governing the mechanics of random fiber networks and provided a better understanding of mechanical properties of biological and manmade materials such as the cell cytoskeleton, extracellular matrix, and paper products. Furthermore, these studies could be used to guide scientific efforts to design new biomimetic materials that possess mechanical and microstructral properties similar to those of natural and biological fibrous materials. The findings of this project appeared in a number of peer-reviewed journal publications. Furthermore, several presentations were given at the national and international conferences and meetings. This project supported a graduate student who defended his PhD thesis successfully. Furthermore, a new graduate course was developed and added to the curriculum.
